title: 107_s930
content: The Grand Canyon Capital Improvements Act of 2001 establishes definitions for terms like fundraising organization, memorandum of agreement, Park, and Secretary. It also outlines the creation of a fundraising organization authorized to act under the Secretary for Grand Canyon National Park. The Secretary may enter into a memorandum of agreement with a fundraising organization to issue taxable bonds for the Park, subject to professional standards and audits. The United States is not liable for the organization's bonds. The fundraising organization must enter a memorandum of agreement detailing the bond issue, maturity not exceeding 20 years, per capita amount for bond repayment and administration costs, funded projects at the Park, responsibilities of the Secretary and organization for each project, and procedures for agreement modifications. The Secretary may authorize the Superintendent of the Park to charge a surcharge of up to $2 per individual in addition to entrance fees collected under various programs. The Secretary may authorize a surcharge of up to $2 per individual in addition to entrance fees collected. The surcharge must be used to amortize bond issue, cover administration costs, and maintain a reserve as determined by the bond underwriter. Bond proceeds under this Act can be used for eligible projects in the Park, subject to certain limitations. Projects must align with laws governing the National Park System, Park-specific laws, and the general management plan. Administrative expenses cannot be covered by bond proceeds, except for interest. Interest earned can be used for reserve requirements and reasonable administrative expenses related to bond management and sale. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress on the bond program within 2 years of regulations being promulgated. The report will review the program at the Park and provide recommendations on establishing a bond program at all National Park System units. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Treasury, will promulgate regulations to implement the Act.
